descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value:
Teaches techniques for creating data visualizations for news reporting, documentary films, marketing communication, non-profit issue awareness, and more. A significant part of the course also reviews research at the intersection of visual communication and psychology, and you will study theories and scholarship on the nature of data imaging humans find visually arresting and informative, and also ask why.
Some of the visualizations you may create are interactive tools like maps, timelines, treemaps, and time-lapse visualizations, as well as static charts and infographics. You will create data visualizations for project ideas you generate yourself, as well as contribute to a larger, single class project that compiles and visualizes data on a topic of importance in Qatar. The course is open to journalism and communication majors of sophomore standing or higher.

name: Topics in Philosophy
overview_of_class: This course will introduce students to a range of philosophical topics, questions, and puzzles. Topics may include: the foundation of morality, free will, personal identity, the nature of minds, the possibility of genuine knowledge, the legitimacy of government, questions about justice and power, the meaning of life, and the nature of death. We are going to approach these topics from a number of different perspectives and use classical and contemporary texts, dialogues, movies, short stories, and podcasts. As we explore these questions, we are going to practice how to identify, understand, and assess arguments, as well as how to challenge basic assumptions, analyze concepts, draw distinctions, and read difficult texts. The goal of this class is to strengthen your ability to think, read, and write critically and to contribute to conversations about perennial human concerns.

name: Topics in Philosophy
overview_of_class: The course addresses the topic of immigration from the standpoint of social and political philosophy. An estimated 244 million people live outside of the country of their birth, often as a result of economic inequality, civil war, environmental degradation, and the desire to reunite with family members. At the same time, states enjoy broad powers to police their borders using violence. The goal of this course is to inform ourselves about the nature of immigration and to critically assess immigration policies from an ethical perspective. Topics may include: border controls and admissions policy, citizenship, human trafficking, the treatment of unauthorized immigrants, the role of immigration in economic development, and the role of gender and race in immigration. As we explore these topics, we will practice reading and critically engaging with argumentative texts, challenging basic assumptions, analyzing concepts, and assessing arguments.

name: Topics in Political Science
overview_of_class: This course provides an introduction to American politics and government. We will explore the US constitution, the three branches of government, the news media, public opinion and political participation, and campaigns and elections. We will follow the American elections with interactive blogs, and end with a comparative and critical perspective on US democracy. An introduction to American politics is essential for students to understand American influence and capacity on foreign policies and current events.

name: Advanced Topics in Political Science
overview_of_class: This course covers various ideologies and schools of Arab thought from the late 19th century up to current times. The intent of teaching and class discussion is to engage with the main principles of ideologies and thinkers that have dominated intellectual activism in the Arab region. The course aims at examining the mixed effect of these ideologies on the Arab world, exploring their approaches to traditional and modern values and structures, and their endeavors to (re)formulate a collective identity. Across the region, before and after the independence of Arab countries, liberalism, Marxism, Arab nationalism and Islamism have continued to rival one another in bidding for popular support and political leadership. Arab intellectuals who belonged to these ideologies strived to absorb, adopt, or reject sheer consequences created by the ?shock of modernity' on socio-political, economic, cultural moral levels. Over the long decades of the 20th century and through the days of the post-Arab Spring, intellectual struggle has engulfed the cultural and political scene in the Arab world, reflecting both the rise and fall of those ideologies.

name: Topics in Religion Studies
overview_of_class: This course examines the development of the classical Islamic scholarly disciplines (fan?n or ?ul?m) central to the formulation of Muslim religious identity. We will focus on key intellectual disciplines such as jurisprudence (fiqh), Prophetic traditions (?ad?th), Qur'anic exegesis (tafs?r), theology (kal?m), philosophy (falsafa), and Sufism (ta?awwuf). Recurrent themes in the course include internal continuities and ruptures, disciplinary complementariness and competition, the social role of Islamic scholars (?ulam??), Orientalist critique, and the crisis of modernity. The course concentrates on the eighth to the twelfth centuries C.E., with some reference to the medieval and modern periods.

name: Research Methods in Comm Studies
overview_of_class: This course provides a general overview of the important components of social science research. Through lecture, discussion, and research projects, we will cover the research process, variables and measurement, data collection and statistical analysis, hypothesis testing, experimental designs and alternative research approaches, reliability and validity, ethical principles in conducting research, and writing research reports using APA style. These concepts will be examined through reviews of: survey research, evaluation research, qualitative studies, and content analysis. Much of the course will rely on evaluation and analysis of published scientific articles focusing on the specific research methods used in order to fully understand the research process.

These concepts will be examined through reviews of: survey research, evaluation research, qualitative studies, and content analysis. Much of the course will rely on evaluation and analysis of published scientific articles focusing on the specific research methods used in order to fully understand the research process.

name: Communication & Technology
overview_of_class: This course presents three approaches to understanding technology and its role in human behavior and society. The course will begin by discussing the factors that inform and shape the design of everyday objects and our virtual world. Next the course will examine the psychological aspects of computer-mediated communication and virtual collaboration, including impression relations, groups dynamics and social networks. Finally, the course will explore the ways in which human communication is situated inside of social and institutional structures. Note that this course is a prerequisite for the Digital Media undergraduate curriculum module.

name: Team Leadership and Decision Making
overview_of_class: The past two decades have witnessed a fundamental transformation in the nature of work. Trends towards empowerment, digitization, and globalization have resulted in organizations that routinely structure work around teams. Teams connect diverse, distributed individuals, empowering them to work collaboratively. Those working in, leading, and studying teams have repeatedly observed that teams can accomplish more than the sum or member capabilities (i.e., synergy), but often accomplish less than would the same individuals working alone (i.e., process loss). This course will explore the forces that affect behavior in teams, and the factors that lead to team success. The course will explore the specific challenges associated with leading teams, some of which include: building and designing teams, managing information sharing within and across teams, structuring effective group decision processes, igniting creative thinking, enabling complex problem solving, managing team diversity and conflict, and managing teams of teams. This is an introductory course, with no prerequisites. We will use a variety of readings, activities, and class activities to build team leadership skills. Because of the experiential nature of the course, attendance at all class meetings is required.

name: Power in Entertainment
overview_of_class: This course examines how power is created, sustained and challenged in entertainment media. Students will learn how and why individuals, groups and corporations achieve and maintain dominance in art, film, television, gaming and digital and social media. Particular attention will be paid to how industries have survived the digital transition. Readings will explore contemporary case studies and debates. Lectures will give theoretical and historical context. This course is intended as an introduction to creative industries and first in a sequence before "Contemporary Television."

name: First-Year Seminar
overview_of_class: This First Year Seminar introduces students to studying, analyzing, and researching environmental and climatology issues from the perspectives of media and communication studies. Climate change presents interesting, and important, challenges for communication. How and why climate change is presented as a topic in political communication, film and television, social media, news and documentaries, and scholarly studies will be explored. Readings are drawn from a combination of research articles, news coverage, websites, government sources, and research institutions specializing in climate change communication. Assignments include attendance, readings and screenings, creating PowerPoint slides, posting discussion items and participating in discussions, 3 short papers of 2-5 pages on various relevant topics, and a final paper of about 10 pages exploring an aspect of climate change communication and media texts or technologies.

name: Bargaining and Negotiation
overview_of_class: 363 focuses upon a variety of theories and research projects that explain and predict behavior within negotiation contexts. These theories will be drawn from a variety of disciplines including organizational behavior, industrial relations, political science, social psychology, and communication. Obviously, much of the class material will be drawn from social scientific theory and research. We will also focus on negotiation within a variety of contexts including collective bargaining, family interactions, sales, and international diplomacy. The primary method of teaching will be lecture and students are encouraged to ask questions and offer examples.

name: Media, Communication, and Environment
overview_of_class: This course focuses on exploring, understanding, and researching questions and issues related to the environment and climate through the study of media and communication. Topics include electronic waste and outer space debris; environmental security; the digitization of the wilderness; outdoor and recreational activities in conjunction with media technologies and electronic information networks; ways of representing and communicating environmental and climatology issues through such examples as climate change communication, weather forecasting, documentaries, and feature-length fictional film, television and similar media; and examples of environmental and climatology-themed government media and communication. Student classwork includes lecture material, readings and audiovisual screenings, discussions, providing relevant discussion materials, and producing a research paper-project relevant to the topics and themes of the course.

name: Communication Studies Research Seminar
overview_of_class: Algorithms, or, more broadly, systems driven by computational actors, are everywhere, and right now we're all trying to figure out just how much influence they do (and should) have over our lives. It seems like a new question, but it can also be seen as an extension of a debate that's been raging about computers specifically since the 1950s and technology in general since a very dangerous external memory technology known as "writing" debuted. The latest iteration of this debate involves all computerized decision making and content recommendation systems, from Facebook's News Feed to search engine results that determine what is or is not "true" for a large portion of the world. We're in a synthesis with these computational actors, for better or worse, and understanding them is a huge step towards understanding the modern world on a deeper level. This course is a tour through the three-way interplay between algorithmically-driven systems, individual human experience and values, and large-scale social structures. We will start broad and philosophical, then take a deep dive to highlight direct impacts on daily life and dispel some of the key myths that surround these technological interlocutors. Along the way, in keeping with the mission of the junior writing seminar, we will deconstruct key articles the literature to identify what makes "good academic writing." This will culminate in your own 20-page research proposal. We will take the explicit position that there is, in fact, no such thing as "good writing" - only low-fidelity drafting, an openness to feedback, and a passion for editing. As such, our focus will be on getting ideas on paper, and then helping each other iterate and turn these ideas into a solid written foundation for scientific inquiry through workshopping and in-depth feedback.

name: Topics in Communication Studies
overview_of_class: This course covers the use of data visualization as a method to communicate stories (narrative visualization) and as a way to explore and analyze data as a method to find new stories (visual analytics). Students will learn to apply core principles of visualization related to perception, color, and visual mapping, while also practicing design skills, and implementing interactive data visualizations using available tools. Critical skills and thinking about data visualization will be developed through the study of rhetoric, advocacy graphics, and ethics. Different types of data will be explored to understand a range of visual forms from networks, to timelines, trees, and maps. Several assignments, both critical and creative in nature, as well as an integrative final project will serve to underscore the concepts taught and provide practice in the craft of data visualization.

name: Topics in Communication Studies
overview_of_class: This course explores health communication from a design perspective. In this course students will explore factors that make conversations in health "difficult," and the possible strategies to overcome such difficulties. By the end of this course students should be able to critically examine difficult conversations in health and have the skills to propose interventions to overcome them.

name: Topics in Communication Studies
overview_of_class: This course is an introduction to what strategic communication is, how it has evolved over time, and how to be successful in using strategic communication methods. Previously, organizational communication stood alone, and other separate organizational fields, such as public relations and marketing existed in a silo. In all of these areas, communication was studied separately and exclusively within limited contexts. Today, strategic communication has evolved due to our use of technology. The way we currently interact has changed how organizations are viewed, studied, and operated within; organizations have become boundary-less. In this course, we will examine organizational theories, processes, and practices that maintain and further strategic communication. A main focus will be the identification, examination, and assessment of stakeholders, both internal and external. Students will also explore organizational change and the practices that help to innovate, as well as challenges involved with management. We will start the course by gaining knowledge about strategic communication, and then we will start to apply it through real-world cases. At the end of this course, students will be able to understand, interact, assess, and communicate effectively within a variety of organizations by using strategic communication methods. This course is the foundational course for the strategic and organizational communication module in the Communication Studies department.

name: Topics in Communication Studies
overview_of_class: This course will interrogate the resurgence of populism in the twenty-first century in its various manifestations, covering a wide range of political and ideological positions from the left to the right and from the progressive to the conservative across the globe. As evident from Brexit and the election of Donald Trump to the US presidency, no geo-political region or national/culture space appears to be immune to the lures of populist movements and moments (episodic gatherings and eruptions). The persistent and historically erroneous assumption that populism is a recurrent feature of politics in developing countries under duress due to crushing poverty or uncontained internal religious or ethnic strife has been suspended for the time being. Populism (along with the very idea of "people" and the "popular rule") are beginning to command renewed public as well as scholarly attention, which is long overdue.

name: Topics in Communication Studies
overview_of_class: How do sexuality, race, gender, and class shape new media? This course explores the role of intersectional identity in technological transformations in media, focusing on the transition from analog to digital. Students will read historical case studies and theoretical essays on such topics as how social media affect how queer users interact and self-identify and how race influences cable TV distribution. The course is organized into three key areas of inquiry - culture, organization, and technology - with the goal of understanding the complex ways they interrelate. It is rooted in black feminism and queer of color critique but introduces a range of epistemologies. It focuses on visual media - art, television, film, games, and social media.

name: Topics in Communication Studies
overview_of_class: This is a seminar course that will examine how algorithms are shaping society (and vice versa). We will cover issues related to income inequality, the 2016 U.S. presidential election, racial and ethnic bias, rural areas, and others topics. The primary weekly activities will be reading "hot-off-the-presses" literature, discussion, and presentation. The primary deliverable will be designing a research project for publication at a prominent scientific publication venue ("researcher track") or the development of a prototype product for release ("practitioner track"). This course will appeal equally to students from McCormick and from the School of Communication, and both types of students will be challenged in their domain of expertise.

name: Modes of Cultural Analysis
overview_of_class: This seminar is designed to introduce students to the opportunities and challenges involved in the cultural analysis of communicative forms, genres, and practices as situated in given contexts and historical moments. Given the complexity of such a task, the course aims not for theoretical or methodological mastery, but seeks to begin the process of mapping relevant traditions and literatures that have influenced recent attempts to connect rhetoric, media and culture. The course will survey some of the concepts of "culture" that have been used to describe and analyze the constitution and consequences of communicative behavior in the past and survey some of the most influential work that has been based upon such conceptualizations. Focusing principally (though not exhaustively) on the Frankfurt School and critical cultural theory traditions, on cultural studies (as articulated initially within British and American contexts), and on anthropological approaches to culture, we will consider how these traditions have engaged political economy, concepts of power and its exercise, and questions of identity, subject, and community formation.
subject: COMM_ST
title: SoC COMM_ST 402-0-20 Modes of Cultural Analysis

title: SoC COMM_ST 525-0-20 Seminar-Problems in Comm Studies
enrl_requirement: Enrollment Requirements: Reserved for Graduate Students.

name: Seminar-Problems in Comm Studies
overview_of_class: How do elite chefs come up with new recipes? What makes blues authentic? What makes a model successful? What is the difference between art and craft? How does an amateur learn glassblowing? Why do people still flock to the opera house? How does a museum store an installation? Is there a career for hip-hop street artists? What kind of job is being a tour guide? Do record studio interns ever get a job? Why do we get the news that we get? And why should we care about all this? This course looks at ethnographies of artistic practice to better understand how culture is made, circulated, and received in social life. Aiming to go beyond the personal idiosyncrasies of individual artists and media players, it shows through a myriad of studies in cultural production, what are the factors that play the greatest role in shaping contemporary cultural production: is it about professional traditions, forms of ownership and funding, government regulations, organizational factors or the social dynamics in the interplay between owners, workers, and audiences? Sorting out the factors that shape cultural production can best be accomplished via comparative research - across geographical regions, and institutional fields. This course offers a theoretical and methodological roadmap to such a project, helping students navigate through the landscape of how contemporary culture is produced.
subject: COMM_ST
title: SoC COMM_ST 525-0-21 Seminar-Problems in Comm Studies

How does an amateur learn glassblowing? Why do people still flock to the opera house? How does a museum store an installation? Is there a career for hip-hop street artists? What kind of job is being a tour guide? Do record studio interns ever get a job? Why do we get the news that we get? And why should we care about all this? This course looks at ethnographies of artistic practice to better understand how culture is made, circulated, and received in social life. Aiming to go beyond the personal idiosyncrasies of individual artists and media players, it shows through a myriad of studies in cultural production, what are the factors that play the greatest role in shaping contemporary cultural production: is it about professional traditions, forms of ownership and funding, government regulations, organizational factors or the social dynamics in the interplay between owners, workers, and audiences? Sorting out the factors that shape cultural production can best be accomplished via comparative research - across geographical regions, and institutional fields. This course offers a theoretical and methodological roadmap to such a project, helping students navigate through the landscape of how contemporary culture is produced.

overview_of_class: The goal of this seminar is to introduce first-year students in the MTS and TSB Ph.D. programs to the fields they cover and how to be a productive and responsible scholar. The course will include a combination of readings, writings, activities, in-class discussions, and guest visits from faculty.

The course will include a combination of readings, writings, activities, in-class discussions, and guest visits from faculty.

descriptions.value: No textbook required.

name: Special Topics Research Seminar
overview_of_class: Networks have come to play an increasingly important role in our understanding of a wide array of human behavior. In communication and the organizational sciences, extraordinary developments in computing and telecommunications have engendered new organizational forms based on fluid, dynamic networks. These new network forms of self-organization are constantly evolving in dynamic communities as new network links are created and dysfunctional ones dissolved. While many writers assert that the capability to nurture networks will differentiate dominant 21st century organizations, little is known about how this important organizational form emerges and evolves. This seminar is intended to review theoretical, conceptual, and analytic issues associated with network perspectives on communicating and organizing. The course will review scholarship on the science of networks in communication, computer science, economics, engineering, organizational science, life sciences, physical sciences, political science, psychology, and sociology in order to take an in-depth look at theories, methods, and tools to examine the structure and dynamics of networks. The majority of class time will be spent discussing the assigned readings. Laboratory exercises will provide experience with network analysis, modeling and visualization tools. A term paper is expected advancing some theoretical, methodological, or computational aspect of network science.
subject: MTS
title: SoC MTS 525-0-20 Special Topics Research Seminar

These new network forms of self-organization are constantly evolving in dynamic communities as new network links are created and dysfunctional ones dissolved. While many writers assert that the capability to nurture networks will differentiate dominant 21st century organizations, little is known about how this important organizational form emerges and evolves. This seminar is intended to review theoretical, conceptual, and analytic issues associated with network perspectives on communicating and organizing. The course will review scholarship on the science of networks in communication, computer science, economics, engineering, organizational science, life sciences, physical sciences, political science, psychology, and sociology in order to take an in-depth look at theories, methods, and tools to examine the structure and dynamics of networks. The majority of class time will be spent discussing the assigned readings. Laboratory exercises will provide experience with network analysis, modeling and visualization tools. A term paper is expected advancing some theoretical, methodological, or computational aspect of network science.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Monge, P. R., & Contractor, N. S. (2003). Theories of communication networks. Oxford University Press, USA.

name: Special Topics Research Seminar
overview_of_class: Digital media create a marketplace where an endless number of options compete for a limited supply of public attention - an environment where building audiences is a prerequisite for making money or exercising influence. This course explains how the preferences and habits of media users, the strategies and constraints of media makers, and the growing prevalence of data and metrics form a dynamic marketplace that shapes public attention. We gain hands-on insights into audience behavior with analyses of comScore data. The topics we cover include theories of media choice, the role of social networks, sharing economies, audience-making strategies, bias in measurement, recommender systems, big data, and audience analysis.

name: Special Topics Research Seminar
overview_of_class: This is a seminar course that will examine how algorithms are shaping society (and vice versa). We will cover issues related to income inequality, the 2016 U.S. presidential election, racial and ethnic bias, rural areas, and others topics. The primary weekly activities will be reading "hot-off-the-presses" literature, discussion, and presentation. The primary deliverable will be designing a research project for publication at a prominent scientific publication venue ("researcher track") or the development of a prototype product for release ("practitioner track"). This course will appeal equally to students from McCormick and from the School of Communication, and both types of students will be challenged in their domain of expertise.

name: Analysis & Performance of Literature
overview_of_class:
Overview of class

The course studies the performance of poetry, short fiction, and non-fiction. It explores how performance helps the performer and audience to understand a text; it considers in what ways a performance can "match" a written text; and it examines the techniques of performance. Students write three critical papers and give three live, graded performances. There are some quizzes and workshops. The class is neither an acting class nor an English class, but it draws on practices fundamental to both. Much of class time will be devoted to performance of texts and rigorous critical discussion of the performances and the works on which they are based. Consequently, attendance is mandatory. It examines the role of the audience in the critical reception of the text. The course is designed for both students with little prior performance experience and those with considerable theatrical experience.

It is an excellent course for students to take who want to become excellent communicators; it hones your professional skills and gives you the poise and confidence to excel in the "real world."

name: Performance Culture and Communication
overview_of_class: The course asks the question: How are stories and storytelling central to our lives and to human communication? We will explore how storytelling performances reflect our families, communities, culture, and nation. To engage the power and significance of storytelling performance we will focus on three units: (1) Oral Narrative. Students will learn how to conduct in-depth interviews, on a particular topic, to gather oral narratives and their meanings from specific family, friends, or community members. (2) Myth. Students will read and discuss ancient and contemporary myths to unravel deeper questions about local and global experiences. (3) News Reports. Through guided instruction students will select a current news story, from electronic or newspaper journalism, they feel reveals an urgent issue they are compelled to share. Each of the three units will culminate in a performance: a solo performance of an oral narrative, a group performance of a myth and, finally, a multi-media group performance of a news story. The course is highly interactive and performance based. The unifying thread and overarching question for the course is: How does storytelling performance and creative communication help us better engage and illuminate our world and the world of others, e.g., identity, family, community, nation, social relations, political institutions and economic orders?

name: Topics in Performance Studies
overview_of_class: How do sexuality, race, gender, and class shape new media? This course explores the role of intersectional identity in technological transformations in media, focusing on the transition from analog to digital. Students will read historical case studies and theoretical essays on such topics as how social media affect how queer users interact and self-identify and how race influences cable TV distribution. The course is organized into three key areas of inquiry - culture, organization, and technology - with the goal of understanding the complex ways they interrelate. It is rooted in black feminism and queer of color critique but introduces a range of epistemologies. It focuses on visual media - art, television, film, games, and social media.

name: Social Art Tactics
overview_of_class: In this course students will explore the historical and theoretical foundations of socially-engaged art and develop performance-based interventions on pressing social issues of their choosing. As a genre, social art practice is concerned with applying the skills of artistic disciplines in the development of activist public interventions. We will analyze artwork focused on social change in a variety of genres from performance art and theatre to digital media and relational art. The goal of the course is to develop a multifaceted understanding of the social and aesthetic value of activist art practices and to rehearse techniques for the development of public art projects. The course will alternate between lecture, discussion, artist visits, and performance workshops.

name: Studies in Performance
overview_of_class: This class provides conceptual and practical tools to help students devise their performance recital. Through critical essays and performance exercises, the course engages performance as analytic, research method, and event. The course gives students the opportunity to explore elements such as text, space, objects, and storytelling from an aesthetic and critical perspective. What are the issues that are central to studies of performance when bodies are on display or when a story is communicated to an audience? In what ways does a poetic rendition of an ethnographic interview make a statement about the politics of the research process, disrupting notions of linearity and authority that characterize Western epistemology? How do narrative voice choices impact the politics of a performance? The aim of the course is to explore performance as a meaning-making practice, paying close attention to the role of embodied behavior in the production, interpretation, and dissemination of knowledge.

name: Practicum: Adaptation/Staging of Texts
overview_of_class:
NOTE ON ENROLLMENT.
The fall 2018 section of 424 is open to interested graduate and upper-division undergraduate
students from any program. The Practicum seminar was initially developed for first-year
students in the Theatre Department's MFA Directing Program. The section of 424 required
for 2018-19 first-year Directing MFAs will be offered, by arrangement with Jessica
Thebus and Katy Walsh, in spring 2019. If you are a first-year Directing MFA, take the
section in spring 2018, not this one.
The Practicum seminar in adaptation for first-year students in the Theatre MFA Directing Program meets once a week for three hours. The seminar addresses four topic areas.
(1) Principles of storytelling for stage adaptations of non-dramatic texts.
(2) Narrators onstage: models for the dynamic interaction of storytelling and dramatic representation.
(3) Pretext analysis: the place of appropriation, allegory, and mash-up in stage adaptation.
(4) Imagining the performance space for plays with narrators.

name: Media Construction
overview_of_class: Through lectures, reading assignments, discussions, in-class screenings, and in-class workshops, this course provides a supportive environment where students are encouraged to take risks and experiment as they discover their narrative voice. Students will have opportunities to work both individually and primarily, collaboratively, in small groups. Students will be introduced to the technical and theoretical components necessary for media construction: narrative, sound, image, and editing. Projects will include audio and video assignments and will culminate in the production of group short films.

name: Analyzing Media Texts
overview_of_class: This course is an introduction to the study and structure of film and other audiovisual media. We will define and examine the expressive and aesthetic power of the basic elements of the moving image. Specifically, the course will investigate, across a variety of different media, modes, and historical periods, the fundamentals of cinematography, especially the shot and its composition; editing; set design, costume, and acting styles; and sound. We will also discuss narrative, genre, documentary, animation, and experimental film. The goal of the course is to acquaint students with a vocabulary specific to film and other audiovisual media, and to provide students with the critical tools required for the accurate description and analysis of the moving image.

name: Studies in Media Topics
overview_of_class: This course examines how power is created, sustained and challenged in entertainment media. Students will learn how and why individuals, groups and corporations achieve and maintain dominance in art, film, television, gaming and digital and social media. Particular attention will be paid to how industries have survived the digital transition. Readings will explore contemporary case studies and debates. Lectures will give theoretical and historical context. This course is intended as an introduction to creative industries and first in a sequence before "Contemporary Television."

Students will learn how and why individuals, groups and corporations achieve and maintain dominance in art, film, television, gaming and digital and social media. Particular attention will be paid to how industries have survived the digital transition. Readings will explore contemporary case studies and debates. name: Radio/Television/Film Genre
overview_of_class: This course will introduce students to masterpieces of an art form that's long been forgotten, but is in the midst of rebirth: radio drama. In the middle decades of the 20th century, radio plays were among the most popular forms of fiction in many parts of the world. Legends have come down about thrillers of the 1930s, but these remain poorly understood, and are not representative of the broad work of experimental writers in the medium. In this class you will learn how radio dramas were made in three historical periods: classic American (1937-54); mid-century British (1954-1974) and contemporary global traditions. We will explore the cultural and political background of each of these contexts, practice how to "read" a radio play, and even do some dramatic radio writing. Some radio dramatists we will consider include: Samuel Beckett, Neil Gaiman, Dylan Thomas, Langston Hughes, Orson Welles, Lucille Fletcher, Tom Stoppard, Gregory Whitehead, Ray Bradbury, Eli Horowitz and Harold Pinter. Students with a background or interest in media history, podcasts, creative writing, theatre history, performance, voice studies or literature are especially welcome.
subject: RTVF
title: SoC RTVF 322-0-20 Radio/Television/Film Genre

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course will introduce students to masterpieces of an art form that's long been forgotten, but is in the midst of rebirth: radio drama. In the middle decades of the 20th century, radio plays were among the most popular forms of fiction in many parts of the world. Legends have come down about thrillers of the 1930s, but these remain poorly understood, and are not representative of the broad work of experimental writers in the medium. In this class you will learn how radio dramas were made in three historical periods: classic American (1937-54); mid-century British (1954-1974) and contemporary global traditions. We will explore the cultural and political background of each of these contexts, practice how to "read" a radio play, and even do some dramatic radio writing. Some radio dramatists we will consider include: Samuel Beckett, Neil Gaiman, Dylan Thomas, Langston Hughes, Orson Welles, Lucille Fletcher, Tom Stoppard, Gregory Whitehead, Ray Bradbury, Eli Horowitz and Harold Pinter. Students with a background or interest in media history, podcasts, creative writing, theatre history, performance, voice studies or literature are especially welcome.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: At the end of this class students will have a deep sense of the craft of radio storytelling, as well as an awareness of the growth, death and rebirth of a major media form in specific historical and political contexts. They will also blend analytical writing with creative expression, becoming more active and critical listeners.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value:
Active attendance: 30%. You must come to class having done the reading and listening, with at least two questions about each drama we will study. Be sure to mark down the time stamp of anything you find particularly odd, interesting or worth discussing. I will call on you for your questions.

· Assignment 1: Review. Select one of the plays studied in Weeks 2-4. Write a professional review of the play, as if to a contemporary audience. Make the case for what is special, problematic or important about it. Why does the play matter to our ears today? 2-4 pages. 20%

· Assignment 2: Scene. In Week 5, students (possible working in groups) will be given a photograph and asked to write a short scene for radio drama inspired by the image. Students will also be asked to provide notes on sound effects, transitions and vocal directions for the actors. 20%

· Assignment 3: Script. Write a short script (8-12 pages) or record a short scene (5-7 minutes) inspired by what you have studied in this class. Your play should in some way update, comment upon or rethink a story, style or convention we have studied in this class. I encourage you to mix things up - write 1960s British drama in the style of contemporary Screen Radio, for instance. 30%

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:

name: Radio/Television/Film Genre
overview_of_class: From Wonder Woman (Patty Jenkins, 2017) to Scandal (Shonda Rhimes, 2012-2018), movies and television shows continue to use tried-and-true melodramatic methods to evoke strong feelings in their viewers. With last-minute rescues, triumphant underdogs, thrilling action, and tear-streaked confrontations, these works harness aesthetic spectacle to stir viewers' emotions, often by foregrounding social concerns and inequities. This course examines the history of screen melodrama and its persistence in contemporary media, interrogating the appeal melodrama continues to have for audiences as well as the ways in which its conventions have morphed over time and across platforms.

name: Radio/Television/Film Genre
overview_of_class:
This class explores the popularity of science fiction in postwar American culture-from late 1945 through the present. This period marks the aftermath of Hiroshima and the rise of television, space technologies, artificial intelligence and genetic engineering; in short, during this time there was a virtual explosion of scientific knowledge. Not coincidentally, science fiction became an extremely popular genre in film, pulp literature, and on television. These media texts used the new science for storytelling purposes, and in so doing transformed scientific change into speculation about social change and utopias.
This "speculative" aspect of science fiction will be the key concern of the course as we look at how the genre imagines social relationships between sexes, races, classes?as well as silicon and human life forms. What kinds of narrative strategies do these texts use to represent new social orders and relations? How has the genre changed over the last forty years, and in what ways can we make comparisons between generic changes and social changes? How has science fiction lent itself to self-reflexive exploration of cinema itself?especially cinematic time and space? And how does it build alternative futures or map dystopian nightmares? These questions form the focus of the various topics in the course. Evaluation is based on essay exams, a final paper/project, and oral presentations. Readings include articles, short stories, and books, and screenings will be required for each class (some screened in class, some on your own).

name: Film, Media & Gender
overview_of_class: This course explores the ways gender, as well as other intersectional axes of difference including sexuality and race, factors into media production, representation, and audience activity. In particular, we'll focus on gender across two predominant media platforms: film and television. We'll also consider gender within both mainstream and independent media production and explore how gender is used to study, construct, and address media audiences. Overall, this course will address how difference becomes a tool of social, cultural, economic, and political power, and how its use both empowers and disempowers various cultural groups.

name: National Cinema
overview_of_class: The goal of this course is to provide students with a firm understanding of the major contributions of Russian film art to world cinema, especially what is often termed Russian, or dialectical, montage, introduced in the early 20th century by Lev Kuleshov and developed by Sergei Eisenstein. Students are expected to gain knowledge in classic Russian cinematography, as well as in the theatrical "method" of Stanislavsky and "biomechanics" of Meyerhold that were influential in shaping Russian film theory and history. In class, students will watch the major films by Protazanov, Eisenstein, Pudovkin, and Vertov and discuss them with the Professor. The primary texts for the course will be the films themselves, but the most important theoretical essays by Kuleshov, Eisenstein, Pudovkin, and Vertov will be provided during the course and discussed in class.

name: Topics in Improv
overview_of_class: Improv & Devising for Writers The processes of script writing and script editing are often conflated. This course aims to separate the writing from the editing and focus solely on writing. Improvisational comedy is a process that requires creating without editing. In this course students will study various principles of improvisational comedy as theory and apply those principles to script writing in order to generate premises and devise scenes without regard for planning or editing. The goal of the course is to erase the idea of writer's block and use the tenets of improvisational comedy to better craft first draft scenes with developed characters and well-defined structure. This is a writing intensive class and students will be required to write a 5-7 page script each week. Students will be required to attend one improv performance of their choice at either The Second City, ImprovOlympic or The Annoyance.

name: Topics in Media Writing
overview_of_class: An examination of the elements of "the procedural," (defined primarily as police, lawyer and medical scripts) with a primary focus on thinking outside of the box of this long-standing go-to for writers. By analyzing structure, characters and location, students will dive into the history of the procedural while working within a contemporary storytelling style. Students will respond to essays, watch video examples, outline, write and workshop a full-length procedural script, coming away with the skills necessary to work within the genre's compelling framework.

name: Topics in Media Writing
overview_of_class: A popular style of modern television writing (Transparent, High Maintenance, Atlanta), the "dramedy," has the strong character components of a comedy while combining the engaging story components of a drama. In this class, we will respond to essays, watch video examples and study the art and craft of the dram-com approach. Students will also examine the process of developing, outlining, and writing a dramedy television series, building their own dynamic characters and locations through the making of a final original script.

name: Topics in Media Writing
overview_of_class:
This course will explore: What are some of the current issues facing the LGBTQIA community that are seen in pop culture/main stream media? Which of the groups within this community are the most underrepresented? Where is LGBTQIA headed in terms of television/theater and what could the future hold? How do you tell a story that centers around LGBTQIA characters using the context of theatre, TV. Students will leave this course with a revised draft of 30 pages of a play, half hour television pilot or first three episodes (10pgs each) of a web series idea.

**NOTE: This course will deal with various issues of a sensitive nature. If you are concerned for your own ability to discuss these topical issues, you should re-evaluate your participation in the class.


The following plays will be used during class:

? HIR - Taylor Mac
? The Kid Thing-Sarah Gubbins
? Stop Kiss-Diana Son

name: Topics in Media Writing
overview_of_class: Suspense is more than a genre, it is also a dramatic element writers of every genre should understand and confidently employ. This course is a screenwriting workshop. While there will be some film study to show how set design, camera and music add to the overall outcome, the focus of this class is on the written word?where suspense begins. Through a combination of lectures, written assignments, classroom critiques of student work, and select reading of feature scripts, students will work to strengthen their suspense-writing skills.

name: Topics in Media Writing
overview_of_class:
The creation of a TV Pilot is a unique, exciting, and demanding task for a writer. In addition to the universal responsibility of telling a compelling story, writers are also charged with setting up a "world" and establishing characters and plotlines that will sustain the show over multiple episodes and seasons.

In this class, we will delve into the processes required to succeed in this challenging endeavor. This includes creation of pitch materials, plot and character development, outlining, creation of a show bible, and ultimately, writing the pilot episode of an original TV series.

The classroom will function as part development workshop and part informal TV writer's room. Through weekly reading and writing assignments we will dissect successful entries into the TV space, and tap into our artistic inspirations to evolve our show concepts. From there, we would collaborate as a class by actively brainstorming and workshopping our scripts and series.

By the end of the quarter, each student will complete a draft of an original pilot script, as well as a short "Series Bible" detailing the broader scope

Upon successful completion of the course, students should be able to do the following:

1. Develop an original creative idea specifically tailored for TV (or other episodic media)

topic: Spoiler Alert: Writing the Dramatic Surprise
overview_of_class: From the surprise ending, to the unexpected second act twist, to the slow-dawning realization, narratives from Oedipus to The Sixth Sense are so often structured around the Big Reveal. "SPOILER ALERT: Writing the Dramatic Surprise" is a course in the mechanics of how the best of those reveals are crafted.

name: Introduction to Acting for the Screen
overview_of_class:
This course will introduce RTVF and Theater students to the craft of acting for the screen.
With an emphasis on the actor/director relationship, it will address practices for creating and portraying
characters as well as the more technical concerns of how actors place themselves in relationship to the
camera for the most effective appearance onscreen. Students in this course will perform in (and, in some
cases, direct) a number of exercises to build acting skills in front of the camera, in projects - both in-class
and out-of-class - designed to focus on cinematic storytelling achieved primarily through performance
rather than primarily through directorial technique, cinematography, editing, and sound design.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Students will learn the fundamentals of film producing, from pre-production through distribution, through the lens of independent/low-budget filmmaking. Emphasis will be placed on both applied research and hands-on practice through serving as producer on a student short film in pre-production or production during the quarter. You will be required to deliver an end-of-quarter pitch presentation supplying a detailed schedule and budget for the short film to which you are attached as a co-producer.

name: Topics in Interactive Media
overview_of_class: This course is specifically designed for beginners (participants who have no background in programming) and it introduces the expressiveness of computing to visual artists. We will learn the basics of procedural thinking and create interactive dynamic compositions, applets, and games by using an open source environment, Processing. The course will enable participants to create their own tools for interaction, movement, and form. Participants who do not plan to pursue programming will have the essential knowledge about procedural thinking and gain tools to communicate efficiently with programmers and establish interdisciplinary collaborations. In addition to weekly design assignments, we will explore interactive games and art works via presentations of participants along with assigned readings.

name: Topics in Interactive Media
overview_of_class: This course will teach basic drawing and design skills for storytellers. Participants will practice with both analog tools (drawing and collage) and digital tools (Photoshop and Illustrator) and learn to combine analog and digital tools to create static images for telling stories. Course will be particularly useful for participants who would like to follow a path in animation, comics-graphic novels, design, photography, or cinematography. Participants will keep a journal, make weekly design and drawing assignments, participate in critique sessions, and make an individual presentation about a design work. The capstone project may include a comics story or a storyboard. No drawing or software skills required for taking this course but participants must be willing to practice drawing through a range of assignments.

name: Topics in Interactive Media
overview_of_class: This course is a workshop for understanding the cultural context of video games through practical use of introductory game creation tools. The course aims to distinguish between how video games extend traditions of artistic exchange and how they offer novel and unexplored modes of communication unique to the medium. The course is designed to engender an active and critical perspective on what games are and how they relate to other cultural texts through analysis, discussion, production, and play. Students will have the opportunity to conceptualize their own game projects and select from a menu of approaches in order to resolve them. Students will be evaluated through active participation, individual exercises, reading responses, presentations, and unit projects in group critique. The course is designed for students with no prior game making experience, although students with experience are welcome to enroll.

name: Topics in Post-Production
overview_of_class: This class will introduce you to the increasingly important post-production art of color timing (and other post-production image processes). You will learn the fundamentals in primary, secondary, and effects color correction, as well as keying and compositing (green screen), stabilizing and tracking. We will work with DaVinci Resolve, an industry-standard for color work. We will also work with parts of Adobe After Effects. You will become familiar with all workflows, including film, DSLR, and RED, and will learn how to integrate projects from Avid, Premiere, and FCP. For good measure, we'll also look at titles and delivery formats for everything from Vimeo to broadcast. If schedule permits, the class will visit a post-production facility in Chicago to observe a professional color grading suite. We'll also mirror the work of creative colorists and the approaches to certain shots and have a short master class from a colorist who will walk students through workflows."No textbooks are needed, but students are encouraged to have a portable hard drive.

name: Lighting and Cinematography
overview_of_class:
This is one of the cornerstone classes of your production experience in the film department at NU. You'll be introduced to Super 16mm film via the Arri SRII. You'll master the bulk of the lightin and grip equipment in the cage. You'll learn about light, color, lenses, emulsion, and film stocks. As well, you'll review the Panasonic HPX.
In addition to the technical side of cinematography, you will begin to explore the artistic side of this art. You will expand on your work in 190 by examining framing and composition, light and shadow, and color as they apply to the moving image. You will work rigorously on your ability to translate meaning, story, and idea into image. As well, you will gain more experience in the collaborative process which is critical in the filmmaking arts.

name: Documentary Production
overview_of_class: In this course, students will examine documentary practices and produce their own shorts. Students will be guided through all the necessary pre-production, production and post-production steps and will create a finished short documentary ready to submit to film festivals, online outlets, or other exhibition venues by the end of the quarter. Students may choose to co-direct with another classmate or work solo. A working knowledge of basic production equipment and editing software is expected, but refresher workshops will be offered as needed. Watching, discussing, and providing feedback for students' work will be a major component of this class. We will also look at a range of documentaries in class to analyze different styles and strategies.

name: Media Historiography
overview_of_class: This course explores the cultural and social history of film, television, and digital media. We will look at scholarship in cultural history, archive theory, media archology, and literary inspired histories of texts and readers, and we evaluate their usefulness for media studies. The course will introduce historical models through which to understand how audiences have gathered as publics for media, and we will explore how media audiences have been mobilized as political communities. We will also examine the contemporary media's role in constructing historical consciousness for audiences. We'll consider how memory serves as a source of alternative historical knowledge that challenges official histories, and we will explore, for example, how people use share sites (like YouTube) to curate and share alternative archives.

We will look at scholarship in cultural history, archive theory, media archology, and literary inspired histories of texts and readers, and we evaluate their usefulness for media studies. The course will introduce historical models through which to understand how audiences have gathered as publics for media, and we will explore how media audiences have been mobilized as political communities. We will also examine the contemporary media's role in constructing historical consciousness for audiences. We'll consider how memory serves as a source of alternative historical knowledge that challenges official histories, and we will explore, for example, how people use share sites (like YouTube) to curate and share alternative archives.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Evaluation is based on class participation and presentations, reading reports, and a final 15-20 page seminar paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: The course readings include theoretical literature on history writing and archive theory, as well as cultural histories of media audiences (such as scholarship on female fans or African American theaters). Books (or chapters from books) include Jacques Derrida, Archive Fever; Michael Foucault (History of Sexuality and Archeology of Knowledge), Ann Cvetkovich (An Archive of Feelings), Miriam Hansen, Babel in Babylon, Ann duCille, Technicolored, and additional readings will be on reserve. Required film/TV screenings will be on reserve in the RTVF media library.

name: Advanced Media Writing
overview_of_class:
To provide students with the tools necessary to pitch, develop, and write a pilot episode of an original half- hour single camera comedy. Current television pilots and series will be analyzed.

The class will replicate as much as possible the atmosphere of the "writers' room" on a sitcom during production. As with a real sitcom staff, the class will offer constructive criticism of each other's work. The various roles in the writer's room will also be explored. Students will pitch an idea for a half hour single camera show and work with other writers on developing a script.
**syllabus subject to change as needed.

name: Advanced Media Writing
overview_of_class: How is story structure related to the construction of meaning for documentary filmmakers? How do aesthetic concerns and stylistic choices reinforce meaning created by story structure? How do documentary filmmakers design, create and explore with practical narrative storytelling techniques in mind? Students will analyze, unpack and study the narrative structure of film forms across the broad spectrum of documentary filmmaking practice. Particular attention will be paid to structural analysis from a creative practitioner's point-of-view, and how structural design plays out in all stages of documentary practice, from pre-production through editing.

name: Seminar: Studies in Film and Video Prod
overview_of_class: This course is focused on expanding students' foundational knowledge of cinematography, sound recording, lighting, and editing specifically for documentary projects. Initially using the Canon C100 camera, students will learn to master the technical and aesthetic challenges and opportunities of shooting non-fiction. Using Adobe Premiere Pro CC software, the editing portion of the course will cover theoretical, organizational, and practical aspects of documentary post-production. The exercises and assignments in this course will build practical skills, while also allowing for aesthetic exploration. Class time will be devoted to the introduction of concepts and various technologies, in-class exercises, viewing relevant documentaries, discussion of techniques, and providing feedback for students' work.

name: Seminar: Studies in Film and Video Prod
overview_of_class: In this course we will explore the integration of production and post-production in digital cinematography. Incorporating what you've learned in 380, the course will use the RED One camera and the Canon C500 camera and their associated workflows. You will learn the hardware of the camera, data management techniques, and certain aspects of post-production software including REDCine-X and integration with Premiere. You'll also explore lighting and exposure techniques and equipment, using the overhead lighting grid in Studio 106, and how to work with two cameras. The class is designed to give you as much hands-on time with the cameras as possible. We'll also discuss the advantages and limitations of digital capture, learn about compression and the various sensors, and discuss the latest developments in the field beyond these two cameras.

name: Documentary Techniques
overview_of_class: In this course, students will be introduced to traditional small-crew documentary filmmaking through the process of directing their own short 6-8 minute project. Students will get hands-on experience shooting, interviewing, recording sound, and editing. In addition to critiquing students' projects in class, we will screen and discuss documentary films, and host visits by guest filmmakers. By speaking with filmmakers and viewing documentaries by a range of directors, students will wrestle with questions such as: What kinds of documentaries are relevant today? What are the ethical obligations of a documentarian? What is the relationship between style and story?

name: Foundations of Writing for Screen & Stage
overview_of_class: This is an intensive writing workshop and an introduction to the art and craft of dramatic writing. Emphasis will be placed on the understanding and practice of the core elements of dramatic works-structure, character, story, dialog, setting, scene development, conflict and pacing. Through a combination of lectures, written assignments, classroom critiques of student writing, and selected readings of texts, plays and screenplays, students will strengthen their writing proficiency across dramatic mediums.
subject: RTVF
title: SoC RTVF 561-0-20 Foundations of Writing for Screen & Stage

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is an intensive writing workshop and an introduction to the art and craft of dramatic writing. Emphasis will be placed on the understanding and practice of the core elements of dramatic works-structure, character, story, dialog, setting, scene development, conflict and pacing. Through a combination of lectures, written assignments, classroom critiques of student writing, and selected readings of texts, plays and screenplays, students will strengthen their writing proficiency across dramatic mediums.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class participation and discussion of reading assignments, weekly writing exercises, completion of a short film screenplay between 15 and 30 pages.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1. The Rhetoric and Poetics of Aristotle
Publisher: Modern Library
ISBN-10: 0075546027
2. Field, Syd, Screenplay, The Foundations of Screenwriting
Publisher: Random House/ Dell Publishing
ISBN 13:978-0-385-33903-2
3. REQUIRED: FORMATTING SOFTWARE
(preferred) FINAL DRAFT 10 Educational

descriptions.name: Class Notes
descriptions.value:
1) This is a writing class. Please be familiar with formatting software before first class. I will be available if you have any questions.
2) Scripts for class reading assignments will be listed in the syllabus and made available online or in handouts.

enrl_requirement: Add Consent: Department Consent Required

name: Full Length Project
overview_of_class:
This is the first in a sequence of three workshop courses that second year MFA students in Writing for the Screen and Stage will complete during the 2018-2019 academic year. After completion of all three courses, each student will have created at least one full-length project for film, theatre or television.

During RTVF 564, students writing a feature film or a play will complete a brief premise/synopsis, a treatment, and the first section of a script. Students writing a television project will complete a premise/synopsis for a series, a plot outline for a pilot and, dependent on episode length, fulfill any additional writing requirements in consultation with the instructor.

name: Theatre History II: Post 1650
overview_of_class: This course explores theatre's histories and counter ? - histories in response to global changes in technology and culture from 1640 to today. Students will engage with readings, lectures, and creative assignments that ?survey canonical and "forgotten" plays, artists, and genres. Through taking an expansive approach to theatre history's well-trodden and neglected corners, students will learn to articulate the ways in which their discoveries ? about theatrical innovations? impact historical narratives.

name: Theatre and Social Change
overview_of_class: This class will examine the long heritage of politically radical theatre in the United States, paying special attention to drama from the 1930s to the present day. Among the movements we will study will be the Group Theater, the Negro Ensemble Company, Living Theater, La Mama Experimental Theater Club, and El Teatro Campesino. To round out the picture, we will read theoretical and aesthetic statements that informed radical theatre movements in the United States, including Marxist, feminist, and anti-imperialist texts, and we will also look at key films?such as those associated with the Russian montage movement?that inspired theatrical practitioners to devise new aesthetic forms to challenge and disrupt the pro-capitalistic, patriarchal, and white supremacist hegemony in the United States.
subject: THEATRE
title: SoC THEATRE 341-0-20 Theatre and Social Change

name: Asian American Theatre
overview_of_class: This course examines the Asian American experience through theatre, performance art, spoken word, stand-up comedy, and social performances. Our objective is to understand how these performances are critical sites and practices in narrating and remembering significant moments in twentieth-century and twenty-first century Asian American history. In doing so, we will discuss the intersectionalities of race, ethnicity, gender, sexuality, and class in relation to topics of im/migration and citizenship; identity and community formation; U.S. imperialism and war; trauma and memory; and social justice and political activism. We will read key works in Asian American history, cultural studies, performance studies, and theatre studies.
subject: THEATRE
title: SoC THEATRE 346-0-20 Asian American Theatre

We will read key works in Asian American history, cultural studies, performance studies, and theatre studies.

name: Transnational Theatre
overview_of_class:
In what ways can theatre matter to the world? How does social and political life shape theatre and vice versa? How does theatre create a new understanding of and engagement with traumatic pasts? This course explores these questions by examining how theatre engages with histories of human rights violations?genocide, disappearances, sexual slavery, apartheid, and other forms of mass violence?in Asia, Latin America, and Africa. We will also explore the work of artists, activists, and survivors in protests, truth and reconciliation commissions, and communal courts, as well as the influence of these different sites of performance on theatre. These performances from the stage and everyday life are embodied public events that engage multiple audiences, allowing people material ways to join in negotiating trauma and enacting personal and collective transformation. We will consider a range of topics such as the politics of memory; historical materialism and knowledge production; the ethics of representing violence; the theatricality of justice; mourning; witnessing; the transmission of trauma; and community formation.

The course is organized into three units focused on six historical case studies: 1) Asia (Japanese military sexual slavery and the Cambodian Genocide), 2) Latin America (the "Dirty War" in Argentina and civil violence in Peru), 3) Africa (the Rwandan Genocide and Apartheid in South Africa). The course begins with acts of witnessing at a war crimes tribunal and dramatizations of the lives of survivors of Japanese military sexual slavery; we will also look at memorializations of and theatrical productions about the Cambodian Genocide. In the second unit, we will consider the relationship between trauma and public mobilization through the activism of the Madres of the Plaza de Mayo in Argentina, the Peruvian truth commission, and the theatrical work of Grupo Cultural Yuyachkani. The last unit focuses on sites of transitional justice such as South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission and Gacaca courts in Rwanda, as well as the ethics of representing violence in plays by Erik Ehn and Yael Farber.
subject: THEATRE
title: SoC THEATRE 348-0-20 Transnational Theatre

name: Transnational Theatre
overview_of_class: Although the postmodern, avant-garde, and contemporary are widely perceived as genres emerging from and residing within the white West, artists of color outside of Euro-America are creating some of the most fascinating and complex work today. Through readings, viewings, and dance practice, this course encounters a handful of contemporary choreographers from sub-Saharan Africa, Asia, and Latin America. We will analyze their choreography through postcolonial and feminist perspectives in order to attend to the structural challenges that the artists face in the afterlife of colonialism and in light of increasing global capitalism. The course asks: as contemporary dance is practiced in multiple sites across the world, what coheres in the category "contemporary dance"? This guiding question will be enriched by themes including transnational circulation, anti-colonial resistance, global feminisms, national identity, state violence, and intercultural collaboration.
subject: THEATRE
title: SoC THEATRE 348-0-21 Transnational Theatre

name: Advanced Acting Topics
overview_of_class:
A Master Class for first year MFA Directors and advanced undergraduate actors examining artistic process, this course will introduce you to the tools and the structure needed to deepen your practice. Over the quarter we will investigate how we can bring a greater sense of innovation and risk taking to our rehearsal process and experiment with new types of rehearsal methodologies. You will learn a rehearsal methodology developed by graduate directing faculty Shana Cooper called Essence Work, a technique which aids theater makers in being responsive to the individual needs of a project. Essence work also enables all artists to contribute more deeply to the creative process, and to take greater ownership over the production. In addition to a close investigation of Essence Work, students will study and execute specific rehearsal exercises and techniques employed by brilliant international artists like choreographer Pina Bausch and French director Ariane Mnouchkine. This course is an opportunity to expand your understanding of and experience with non-traditional rehearsal methods and techniques. It will help you to break open your habits of creation and storytelling, and develop the tools to innovate your artistic process and the work generated by that practice. Both directors and actors will physically participate during in-class explorations.

In addition to first year graduate directors, this class is open to undergraduate Junior and Senior acting majors by permission only. Interested undergrads please submit a paragraph that expresses your interest, as well as listing your year, primary acting professor, and significant acting experience to Professor Shana Cooper at shanacooper@northwestern.eduand copy TA Alex Mallory at alexmallory@u.northwestern.edu.

Essence work also enables all artists to contribute more deeply to the creative process, and to take greater ownership over the production. In addition to a close investigation of Essence Work, students will study and execute specific rehearsal exercises and techniques employed by brilliant international artists like choreographer Pina Bausch and French director Ariane Mnouchkine. This course is an opportunity to expand your understanding of and experience with non-traditional rehearsal methods and techniques. It will help you to break open your habits of creation and storytelling, and develop the tools to innovate your artistic process and the work generated by that practice. Both directors and actors will physically participate during in-class explorations.

In addition to first year graduate directors, this class is open to undergraduate Junior and Senior acting majors by permission only. Interested undergrads please submit a paragraph that expresses your interest, as well as listing your year, primary acting professor, and significant acting experience to Professor Shana Cooper at shanacooper@northwestern.eduand copy TA Alex Mallory at alexmallory@u.northwestern.edu.

name: Advanced Acting Topics
overview_of_class:
A laboratory for second and third year MFA Directors and advanced undergraduate actors enabling the exploration of artistic process, this course will offer a constructive, collaborative environment in which to deepen your practice as a director or actor. Directors will bring in alternative rehearsal techniques that they are interested in investigating in relationship to upcoming directing projects. Through challenging the assumptions of their own artistic processes, directors will encourage their fellow artists to break open their own artistic process and engage with the work in new and unexpected ways. This course is an opportunity to push your own boundaries and traditions of how you tend to make work. It's an opportunity to break open your habits of creation and styles of storytelling, and to discover methods that challenge both you and your collaborators to rise to meet the specific challenges of the project at hand rather than a one-size-fits-all model of creation. Actors and directors will engage in the study and discussion of alternative rehearsal methodologies as well as participate as actors during the in-class laboratory environment.?

In addition to second and third year graduate directors, this class is open to undergraduate Junior and Senior acting majors by permission only. Interested undergrads please submit a paragraph that expresses your interest, as well as listing your year, primary acting professor, and significant acting experience to Professor Shana Cooper atshanacooper@northwestern.edu and copy MFA Director Alex Mallory atalexmallory@u.northwestern.edu.

name: Seminar-Studies in Theatre
overview_of_class: This course is designed to aid graduate director/dramaturg teams as they prepare for their productions. Readings and discussion about the nature of collaboration, as well as the tools and duties of the dramaturg, will be explored. In addition to the common reading, each team will be given various projects to complete that they will need to tailor to suit their specific production. While learning to work together, both the director and the dramaturg will also be learning intensive research skills, as well as how to apply that research to a real production environment, while thinking critically and writing persuasively about how and why that research is necessary and useful. Guest speakers will provide additional insight into the professional experience of the dramaturg at large.

name: First-Year Seminar
topic: Passing and the Performance of Identity in America
overview_of_class: This first-year seminar will be an intensive, multi-genre study of literary and cinematic works that focus on the phenomenon of "passing" and the reinvention of identity from the turn of the 20th through the turn of the 21st century. Through film, literature and other expository writings, this seminar will explore the various ways in which notions of class, gender, race, sexuality and other identities are socially constructed performances. Performance covers various modes of human communication?from how we use language to storytelling to cultural rituals. Some of the questions we will consider in this seminar are: how do various identities relate to one another or do they? What are some of the ways in which we perform versions of ourselves daily based on the expectations of those around us? Finally, when are these social constructions of identity fluid, interchangeable, temporary or permanent?

name: Introduction to African American History: Key Concepts from 1700-1861
overview_of_class: This course covers the development of the group of people known today as African Americans. This history is rooted in the cultures of Africa, Europe and the Americas; the experience of the Trans-Atlantic slave trade; the exploration and colonization of North America; and the founding of the United States as a nation distinct from the rest of the Americas. Central to this history is an understanding of slavery and freedom; the development of ideas of race and racism; and the human rights struggle embodied in the anti-slavery movement, which would lead to the end of slavery in the United States.
