name: Latin America: Studies in Culture and Society
overview_of_class:
Contemporary Art and Visual Culture of the Caribbean

This seminar course on contemporary art and visual culture of the Hispanic Caribbean explores how the region has been represented and imagined from the early twentieth century to the present. Interdisciplinary in nature, this course pays particular attention to the role of certain political and historical events in shaping visual production and effecting the dissemination of certain types of images. We will explore visual, literary, political and historical texts such as the artwork by Cuban performance artist Tania Bruguera and films such as Arte de hacer ruinas (Cuba), La ciudad perdida (Puerto Rico), En el tiempo de las mariposas (Dominican Republic) and Memorias del subdesarrollo (Cuba). From this course students can expect to gain an understanding of how the Caribbean has been represented in contemporary art and visual culture and how a more nuanced approach to these representations can help us gage their social contributions.

name: Topics in Latin American, Latina and Latino, and Iberian Literatures and Cultures
topic: Sexual Dissidence & Activism in Latin America: AID
overview_of_class:
The AIDS epidemic in the 1980s and 1990s produced a new body and subjectivity. While the Global North experienced loss, mourning and activism for retroviral therapy, in the Global South too there was an emergency for viral knowledge and political recognition/inclusion. This course looks to situate the AIDS epidemic in the Latin American historical context while, at the same time, introducing its aesthetic manifestations.

Taught in English.

name: Dissertation Prospectus Writing Workshop
overview_of_class: This course seeks to impart to students the knowledge necessary to answer the questions: what is a dissertation, and how do I write one? In the spirit of a workshop, we will work as a group to foster and cultivate the skill sets necessary to formulate and articulate an organizing question adequate to the charge of a significant, independent, multi-year research project. We will call this first stage the prospectus, and we will figure out what it is and how best to write it. We will try to distill multiple and often conflicting statements, expectations, and/or fears about what the dissertation is so we can effectively undertake its preparation and writing.

name: First-Year Seminar
overview_of_class: Cryptology is the study of secret writing, or more generally secure communication. We will discuss classical methods of cryptography, followed by the use of the German Enigma machine during World War II, and end by discussing modern cryptosystems such as RSA and PGP, digital signatures, and their use in internet security.

We will discuss classical methods of cryptography, followed by the use of the German Enigma machine during World War II, and end by discussing modern cryptosystems such as RSA and PGP, digital signatures, and their use in internet security.

name: Introduction to Statistics
overview_of_class: This course introduces students to the discipline of statistics as a science of understanding and analyzing data. Students will learn how to collect data, how to analyze data, and how to use data to make inferences and conclusions about real world phenomena. Students will also learn how to be better consumers of everyday statistics - news, social media, infotainment, etc.
subject: STAT
title: WCAS STAT 202-0-20 Introduction to Statistics

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This course introduces students to the discipline of statistics as a science of understanding and analyzing data. Students will learn how to collect data, how to analyze data, and how to use data to make inferences and conclusions about real world phenomena. Students will also learn how to be better consumers of everyday statistics - news, social media, infotainment, etc.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Mastery of high school algebra.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: 1. Recognize the importance of data collection, identify limitations in data collection methods, and determine how they affect the scope of inference. 2. Use statistical software to summarize data numerically and visually, and to perform data analysis. 3. Have a conceptual understanding of the unified nature of statistical inference. 4. Apply estimation and testing methods to analyze single variables or the relationship between two variables in order to understand natural phenomena and make data-based decisions. 5. Model numerical response variables using a single or multiple explanatory variables. 6. Interpret results correctly, effectively, and in context without relying on statistical jargon. 7. Critique data-based claims and evaluate data-based decisions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will be evaluated through (1) responses to requests for discussion/comment on topics through Canvas; (2) online homework; (3) labs/activities; (4) a midterm exam and; (5) a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: free online textbook, OpenIntro Statistics 3rd Edition (https://www.openintro.org/stat/textbook.php)

name: Introductory Statistics for the Social Sciences
overview_of_class: This class is titled Introductory Statistics for the Social Sciences. We will cover descriptive statistics, probability, random variables, sampling distributions, confidence intervals, and significance tests. At the end of the term, we will introduce regression.
subject: STAT

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This class is titled Introductory Statistics for the Social Sciences. We will cover descriptive statistics, probability, random variables, sampling distributions, confidence intervals, and significance tests. At the end of the term, we will introduce regression.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: We will meet in lecture three times per week. We will meet in section once per week.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Grades will be based on problem sets, two midterm exams, and a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Suggested)
descriptions.value: The textbook for the course is Statistics for Business and Economics (Eighth Edition) by Paul Newbold, William L. Carlson, and Betty M. Thorne. We are using Statistics for Business and Economics: Second Custom Edition for Northwestern University, which includes just the first 11 chapters from the eighth edition. The ISBN-13 is 978-1-256-86179-9.

name: Data Science, 1
overview_of_class: As the initial course in the STAT 301 Data Science series, our objective is to build foundational analytical skills and knowledge for data science. While many data science problems will require knowledge of multiple coding languages and technologies, this course chooses to utilize R and RStudio to conduct data science. Students will develop skills to effectively manage, manipulate, and analyze data in R. These skills will be developed through project/lab based learning (1-2 projects/labs per week). The skills developed in this course are necessary for STAT 301-2 and STAT 301-3.
subject: STAT
title: WCAS STAT 301-1-20 Data Science, 1

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: As the initial course in the STAT 301 Data Science series, our objective is to build foundational analytical skills and knowledge for data science. While many data science problems will require knowledge of multiple coding languages and technologies, this course chooses to utilize R and RStudio to conduct data science. Students will develop skills to effectively manage, manipulate, and analyze data in R. These skills will be developed through project/lab based learning (1-2 projects/labs per week). The skills developed in this course are necessary for STAT 301-2 and STAT 301-3.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: At least a basic understanding of statistics is necessary (i.e. STAT 202 or 210). Some basic familiarity with R is desirable, but not entirely necessary as long as an effort is made to learn some basic R outside of class. Students should be prepared to spend approximately 5 to 9 hours outside of class working on this course - dependent on knowledge of R.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: (1) Students will be able to identify and follow the general steps/stages required to complete a typical data science project; (2) Students will learn and demonstrate the use of standard data science tools necessary to effectively and efficiently import, transform, visualize, model, and communicate data; and (3) Students will learn and demonstrate the use of programming techniques to further augment standard data science tools. (4) Students will be able to conduct and properly communicate a thorough exploratory data analysis.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: A typical class will devote about 10-20 minutes to discussion/lecture with the remaining time devoted to projects/labs where students will either work by themselves or in groups. Students will be expected to adequately prepare for each discussion/lecture by reviewing assigned material (e.g. readings, videos, etc?) because the majority of class time will be spent working on projects/labs - designed around the assigned material. Students will be expected to collaborate and engage with other students to help each other learn and solve problems. There will be a final project in place of a final exam.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: (1) R for Data Science by Hadley Wickham & Garrett Grolemund - Free online version: http://r4ds.had.co.nz/. (2) Students are expected to bring a laptop to class. This requirement will not prevent students from taking this course. If access to a laptop is an issue, then please contact the course instructor and an accommodation will be made.

name: Statistical Methods
overview_of_class: We will develop fundamental concepts of probability and statistical theory, with applications. Topics include sample spaces, probability measures, conditional probability, independence, random variables, distributions, expected values, variance, and limit theory. The sequels (320-2,3) emphasize statistical inference.

name: Survey Sampling
overview_of_class: Statistics 325 covers the essential statistical principles used in sampling human populations and many other populations. Topics include (1) sample designs such as simple random, stratified, and cluster sampling, (2) choosing the appropriate statistical estimators to use in conjunction with a given design, (3) accounting for non-response, and (4) estimating the sampling variances of estimators. The course does not cover questionnaire design.
subject: STAT
title: WCAS STAT 325-0-20 Survey Sampling

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: Statistics 325 covers the essential statistical principles used in sampling human populations and many other populations. Topics include (1) sample designs such as simple random, stratified, and cluster sampling, (2) choosing the appropriate statistical estimators to use in conjunction with a given design, (3) accounting for non-response, and (4) estimating the sampling variances of estimators. The course does not cover questionnaire design.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value:
i) Calculus at level of Math 234 (multiple integration and vector calculus), and (ii) Two previous courses in probability and statistics, including at lease one at the 300 level in either Statistics (other than Stat 330), Econometrics, IE/MS, Math or MMSS.

If you do not meet both prerequisites (i) and (ii), you need permission of instructor. The formal mathematical level is not high but the conceptual level is challenging for many undergraduates. Statistics majors are encouraged but not required to take Stat 320 first. Graduate students should take Stat 461.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Class attendance/participation, homework, midterm, and final paper.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
ISBN: 978-0495105275;
Sampling: Design and Analysis (2nd Edition);
Sharon L Lohr;
Brooks/Cole, Cengage Learning.

name: Applied Statistics for Research I
overview_of_class: This course is primarily for graduate students who intend to design studies and analyze data. This course stands by itself and also serves as a background for further statistics courses, helping to provide the intuition which can sometimes be lost amid the formulas. Topics to be discussed include design of experiments, descriptive statistics, correlation and regression, probability, sampling, estimation and testing.

name: Applied Multivariate Analysis
overview_of_class:
The primary goal of this course is to present statistical methods for describing and analyzing
multivariate data, data in which the response is multidimensional. Topics covered will include principal component analysis, canonical correlation, multidimensional scaling, factor analysis, and clustering. Although the statistical theory behind the methods will be discussed, the course will emphasize the statistical and geometric motivation for the methods, the practical application of the methods, and the interpretation of the results. Given the nature of the data, and the methodology used, linear algebra plays an important role in the course. Thus, a second goal of the course is to present topics in linear algebra that are useful in understanding
statistical methodology.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: STAT 350 or a similar course on regression analysis; linear algebra at the level of Math 240.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
1. To understand important properties of multivariate distributions;
2. To understand the statistical and geometric bases for multivariate statistical methods, including principal components analysis, canonical correlation analysis, factor analysis, multidimensional scaling and cluster analysis;
3. To be able to apply multivariate statistical methods using R and to be able to interpret the results
4. To understand the role of linear algebra in multivariate statistical methodology

name: Topics in Statistics
overview_of_class: We will discuss the design and analysis of randomized controlled trials (RCT), primarily with human subjects. Class meetings will consist of student led presentations of the assigned reading materials. Students will prepare summaries of selected in-depth topics on the design and analysis of RCT's. As a final project, each student will prepare their own statistically designed protocol for an investigation of an intervention of their choice.

name: Human Rights Statistics
overview_of_class: We consider uses of statistics ? as numbers and as methodology ? for use in the context of Human Rights (HR). We take as HR those stipulated in existing international laws. The emphasis of the course is on the discovery and critique of statistical methods used in the HR context, including development, analysis, interpretation, use, and misuse of statistical data for description, assessment, evaluation, and political action. Examples of HR topics include missing females, deaths of combatants and noncombatants from war, disappearances, criminal justice, violence against women, trafficking, child labor, profiling, free elections, hunger, refugees, poverty, illegal immigration, hate crimes and discrimination
subject: STAT

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: 2 of 325, 350, 320-2,3; ECON 381-1,2; MATH 386-1,2; IEMS 303, 304; or consent of instructor.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value:
a. Describe ways that different statistical methods are used in different areas of human rights
b. Interpret the analyses based on the application of the methods for human rights
c. Understand how statistics are misused - intentionally and unintentionally - in the human rights context
d. More readily tease out and critique unstated assumptions behind statistical analyses
e. Identify human rights issues to which statistical methods and statistical data could be applied more effectively
f. Identify problems that need development of new statistical methods
g. Begin to develop and/or improve new statistical methods for human rights work (graduate students and the exceptional undergraduate)
h. Students will become acquainted with some methods new to them, but that is not a primary goal or emphasis of the course.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: Seminar; 2 80-minute meetings per week. The discussions often are led by the students. Extensive readings are required, and students are required to participate even when others lead the discussions.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Students will make 2 class presentations as seminar leader (@20% of grade) and submit 1 preliminary draft (@10% of grade) and 1 final draft (@15% of grade) of a 20-page term paper. Students will also be graded on their participation in seminar discussions led by others (35% of grade). Students are required to meet multiple times with instructor to: develop presentation, choose term paper topic, and review rough draft of term paper (points subtracted from grade if students skip meetings or are unprepared).

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: Reading materials are provided in CANVAS or through electronic reserve at the library. No textbook purchase is required

enrl_requirement: Enrollment Requirements: Prerequisites: Students must have completed any two of the following courses: STAT 325, STAT 350, STAT 320-2, STAT 320-3, ECON 381-1, ECON 381-2, MMSS 386-1, MMSS 386-2, IEMS 303, IEMS 304; or receive permission from instructor to enroll in this course.

name: Intr to Statistical Theory & Methodology
overview_of_class: The goal of the Statistics 420 sequence is to provide a comprehensive introduction to statistical theory and methodology at a level not requiring advanced probability theory (i.e., measure theory). Statistics 420-1 covers distribution theory. Distribution theory is concerned with probability distributions of random variables, particularly those concepts that arise frequently in statistical theory. The emphasis on this course is on the precise and careful statement of results and on the accurate determination of quantities such as moments, distribution functions, and so on, that are often used in statistical methodology. Prerequisites: A good background in calculus, real analysis (e.g., the concept of a limit), linear algebra, elementary probability theory, and statistical methods.

name: Generalized Linear Models
overview_of_class: This course will focus on the theory and application of linear and generalized linear models and related statistical topics. Generalized linear models are a very broad family of statistical models, loosely described as follows. The response variable has a distribution in an exponential dispersion family and the mean response is related to covariates through a link function and a linear predictor. Generalized linear models allow a unified theory for many of the models used in statistical practice, including normal theory regression and ANOVA models, loglinear models, logit and probit models for binary data and models for gamma responses and survival data.

name: Advanced Topics in Statistics
overview_of_class: Statistics 461, Theory of Statistical Data Mining, focuses on theoretical framework, definitions, and rigorous mathematical proofs. We will study the underlying theory and methods for modeling binary responses with multiple explanatory variables. Potential topics include: statistical decision theory, classification, approximation, consistency, mixtures of models, linear combinations, likelihood-based methods, Bayesian methods.

name: Swahili I
overview_of_class: This is the first part of a three-quarter sequence of beginning Swahili. The course equips learners with the necessary listening, speaking, reading and writing skills so as to understand basic Swahili. We shall learn about the history of Swahili language, its place in East Africa, and discuss how to interact with Swahili speakers in culturally appropriate ways. Through a combination of lectures, lab sessions and performance of cultural and communicative activities, learners will gain an understanding of basic Swahili grammatical structures and cultural insights of the people of East Africa. No prior knowledge of Swahili is required to enroll in this course.
subject: SWAHILI
title: WCAS SWAHILI 111-1-20 Swahili I

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first part of a three-quarter sequence of beginning Swahili. The course equips learners with the necessary listening, speaking, reading and writing skills so as to understand basic Swahili. We shall learn about the history of Swahili language, its place in East Africa, and discuss how to interact with Swahili speakers in culturally appropriate ways. Through a combination of lectures, lab sessions and performance of cultural and communicative activities, learners will gain an understanding of basic Swahili grammatical structures and cultural insights of the people of East Africa. No prior knowledge of Swahili is required to enroll in this course.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: On completion of the course, students should be able to appreciate basic cultural practices of the Swahili speaking people. They should also comprehend basic Swahili, and use simple grammatical constructions to perform day-to-day linguistic functions such as greetings, self-introduction and interpersonal conversations.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The final grade will be based on the following six major areas of language use: attendance and participation (10%), homework (15%), weekly vocab quizzes (15%), two sit-in quizzes (20%), Mid-term exam (20%) and final exam (20%). Each learner who attends at least three-language/conversation table meetings will be awarded an extra-credit of 3 points to be added to the final grade.

descriptions.value:
(these texts also apply to the Winter and Spring "Swahili I" courses):

2) Swahili Exercises: A Workbook for First Year Students by Lioba Moshi.
3) Swahili-English, English-Swahili Practical Dictionary (Hippocrene Practical Dictionary) by Nicholas Awde.

name: Swahili II
overview_of_class: This is the first part of a three-quarter sequence of Intermediate Swahili. The course builds on the foundation established in beginning Swahili. It is designed to enhance students' communicative skills and a deeper cultural awareness about Swahili and East Africa. To enroll in the course, a student is required to have satisfactorily completed the three levels of beginning Swahili or the equivalent.
subject: SWAHILI
title: WCAS SWAHILI 121-1-20 Swahili II

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first part of a three-quarter sequence of Intermediate Swahili. The course builds on the foundation established in beginning Swahili. It is designed to enhance students' communicative skills and a deeper cultural awareness about Swahili and East Africa. To enroll in the course, a student is required to have satisfactorily completed the three levels of beginning Swahili or the equivalent.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: The course will generally focus on polishing and enhancing student comprehension and communicative skills. Although the primary goal of the course is to strengthen the five skill areas of reading, writing, speaking, listening and culture, emphasis will be placed on the productive and receptive oral-aural skills of speaking and listening respectively. There will, therefore, be a deliberate tilt towards conversation practice as a means of strengthening student competence in communicative skills.

descriptions.name: Teaching Method
descriptions.value: The class employs a combination of lectures, lab sessions and group performances, and will be conducted almost exclusively in Swahili with a lot of conversation practice. Authentic texts will be introduced to supplement the primary textbook, covering various Swahili registers, including but not limited to literary excerpts, newspaper articles, radio broadcasts and other available Swahili material. Such materials are aimed at introducing the students to current and more specialized Swahili vocabulary. Students will engage in Swahili cultural activities and class presentations that will be conducted mainly in Swahili. By the end of the course, students are expected to be able to understand and express themselves orally and in writing at an intermediate level.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: The final grade will be based on the following six major areas of language use: attendance and participation (10%), homework (15%), weekly vocab quizzes (15%), two sit-in quizzes (20%), Mid-term exam (20%) and final exam (20%). Each learner who attends at least three-language/conversation table meetings will be awarded an extra-credit of 3 points to be added to the final grade.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value:
1. Sharifa Zawawi. 2001. Kiswahili Kwa Kitendo: An Introductory and Intermediate Course (2nd Edition). Africa World Press: New Jersey.
2. Sharifa Zawawi. 1998. Jifunze Kiswahili Chetu: Workbook. Africa World Press: New Jersey. Africa World Press: New Jersey.
3. Swahili - English, English - Swahili Practical Dictionary (Hippocrene Practical Dictionary) by Nicholas Awde.
